author: Tanveer Mann
title: If you haven’t heard of ‘smishing’ scams here’s what you need to know
text:
Bank customers are being warned of new text message scam called ‘smishing’ – also known as SMS phishing (Picture: Getty Images) Bank customers are being warned about a new text message scam known as ‘smishing’ after three Santander customers lost a total of £36,300 in the last month. The scam involves fraudsters sending out text messages to victims pretending to be from their bank. Beware of Aldi scam offering you free £65 vouchers towards your shopping They use a tactic called number spoofing which makes the text message appear on an existing thread of genuine messages from the bank to make them look more convincing. Once received, it asks you to update personal details or to speak to you urgently. Ruth Quinn, from Kent, Ron Williams, from Southampton and Rod Owens, from Coventry, have all been victims to this scam, having had £15,000, £12,000 and £9,200 stolen over the past month, according to This is Money. It is not clear whether the fraudsters targeted the victims knowing they banked with Santander or whether they were randomly targeted. Mother and daughter behind £335,000 sham marriage scam jailed Yet to make it worse for the victims, Santander has refused to refund the money on the grounds of negligence. Each of the victims called the number sent to them and were asked to generate a one-time password. The scammers then used this and account information they had gathered to retrieve all the money they could.

How to avoid falling victim to smishing scams

  • Never share personal or security details such as your PIN or full password
  • Don’t immediately assume an email is genuine – even if it looks really official.
  • Don’t feel pressured into responding back to an email or call – if it’s a genuine organisation, they will let you take your time.
  • If you feel something isn’t quit right, it probably isn’t.
  • Only call a number that you know is genuine (the bank’s number can be found on the back of your card).
Rod Owens noticed money was missing from his account 48 hours after the cash was stolen. But he says his bank did not alert him that such a large payment was leaving his account. According to a letter seen by This is Money from Santander’s fraud department, the bank told him: ‘We have come to the decision to decline your fraud claim. ‘You have given a 3rd party your security details from your online banking. The disputed transactions have been authorised using our OTP service. MORE: 200-year-old bank note returned to museum decades after it was stolen ‘A text message was sent to your registered mobile phone number and entered correctly into online banking to authorise the transactions. ‘For this reason we are unable to reimburse your account in full. However, due to the transactions taking place inside your overdraft, we have agreed to reimburse the amount of £1,500.’ Campaigners storm Southbank Centre to protest talk by ‘rapist’ The three customers now reportedly face going to the Financial Ombudsman about the fraud. The increasing problem of fraud was highlighted in recent figures from Financial Fraud Action UK. In 2016, the UK lost £2 million each day as a result of financial fraud and the overall scale of financial fraud was £768.8 million – an increase on the £755 million lost in 2015.
